div.p: Greetings. I recently wrote while bedridden through our Liner. I had also written earlier through the bookseller of this city; but I have received no response to either of these letters yet. By the grace of the Lord, I am now better and walking again. I sent Felice to Lausanne, as I mentioned in previous letters; I have explained what is contained in this note for him; as for the rest, there is no need for you to be concerned; for I will not accept anything for the time he was with me. I would have gladly kept him longer, if it had been in accordance with both your wishes and his conveniences.

It is enough for me that you understand that I and all my affairs are at your disposal and that I am glad to have had this small opportunity to show that the memory of your kindnesses has not faded with me. Since Liner left us, I have received nothing of any importance; I am waiting to see what you receive from the Frankfurt fair.
Steiger, my father-in-law, my wife, brothers, and all friends send you many greetings.
You can reply through this boy, if you have anything to write back.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, my esteemed lord and dearest compatriot.
